message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, especially the widespread pain and tenderness, suggest that the most likely diagnosis is fibromyalgia. Polymyositis usually comes with proximal muscle weakness, while major depressive disorder has more psychological symptoms. Rheumatoid arthritis causes joint inflammation and damage, which is not seen in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest fibromyalgia, which is characterized by widespread body pain, stiffness, and tenderness. The normal complete blood count and erythrocyte sedimentation rate suggest that there is no inflammation or infection, ruling out other options like polymyositis and rheumatoid arthritis. Major depressive disorder can cause physical symptoms, but it does not explain the tenderness and tingling in specific areas.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms match fibromyalgia, which is characterized by body aches, morning stiffness, and tender points. Polymyositis is characterized by muscle weakness, major depressive disorder by persistent feelings of sadness, and rheumatoid arthritis by joint pain and swelling.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of body aches, stiffness worse in the morning, and tenderness in certain areas suggest fibromyalgia. Polymyositis will show weakness instead of tenderness, and Rheumatoid arthritis will show joint involvement. Major depressive disorder does not explain the physical symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest fibromyalgia as it is associated with generalized body pain, stiffness, and tenderness. Polymyositis is associated with muscle weakness, not tenderness. Major depressive disorder is associated with low mood and anhedonia, not body pain. Rheumatoid arthritis is associated with joint pain and swelling, not diffuse body pain.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms are suggestive of fibromyalgia, which is characterized by widespread pain and tenderness, morning stiffness, and fatigue. The exam findings of tenderness over specific points (i.e. tender points) also support this diagnosis. The absence of abnormalities in blood count and erythrocyte sedimentation rate supports the diagnosis of fibromyalgia over other options such as Polymyositis or Rheumatoid arthritis. Major depressive disorder may be comorbid with fibromyalgia but would not explain the specific tender points found on examination.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of body aches, stiffness worse in the morning, and tenderness over specific areas suggest fibromyalgia. Polymyositis would have muscle weakness and elevated muscle enzymes. Major depressive disorder would have more psychological symptoms. Rheumatoid arthritis would have joint swelling and inflammation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms presented are consistent with fibromyalgia, which often manifests as chronic body aches and tenderness in specific points such as the trapezius muscles and knee medial aspect. Polymyositis involves muscle weakness and elevated muscle enzymes. Major depressive disorder may also include body aches, but not the tender points. Rheumatoid arthritis involves joint pain, swelling, and often shows elevated inflammatory markers.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient displays symptoms of fibromyalgia, including body aches, stiffness in joints, and tenderness over specific points on the body. The other options are less likely based on the given information.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest fibromyalgia, as it presents with body-wide pain, morning stiffness and tenderness at specific points. The other options do not match the symptoms described.
